documents.title: good evening
text: let this serve as a metaphor for running out of puff .
there were so many ejections in the house today , it seemed at least possible that labor could run out of questioners .
a depleted opposition front bench after numerous expulsions during question time in the house of representatives , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers i 'm just running out of juice .
it 's been a big week , and your company has been utterly delightful .
but let 's part ways for now .
today , thursday .
the government confirmed it would support america in the event washington asked us to join a coalition of the willing in airstrikes over northern iraq .
labor asked for a briefing on the latest developments and reserved its position on whether we should join an escalation .
the higher education reforms went into the parliament .
australian reached a new understanding with indonesia on security and intelligence .
a new review of the renewable energy target suggested a dramatic windback of the current scheme .
environment groups and renewable energy groups promptly went the nut .
it sounds neat and orderly , but it really was n't .
gabi chan is back driving politics live next week , bless her .
take care until we meet again .
shadow environment minister mark butler .
bipartisanship looking a long shot at this point .
this is a political document not an independent review .
the climate change denialism endemic in the coalition is written throughout this document .
this is a report written by climate change deniers , for climate change deniers , and it shows .
the recommendations contained in the warburton report put 24,000 clean energy jobs at risk and will freeze the billions of dollars in investment that is already in the pipeline .
the ai group is urging the government to tread carefully and seek a bipartisan approach to the future of the ret .
that 's a polite way of saying please spare us a crap shoot in the senate .
in response to the report , the government should take a pragmatic approach to the ret , and pursue a bipartisan agreement on the basis of a variation of the 20 % target .
that would benefit energy users , respect existing investments and provide a workable foundation for future investment .
the kids from the aycc are still down the front as the light fades on parliamentary thursday .
australian youth climate coalition demonstrate outside parliament thouse in canberra this evening thursday 28th august 2014 bowers
lots of very cranky people around this afternoon .

vestas the world 's largest supplier of wind turbines this shows a fundamental lack of understanding about how power stations are planned and financed , and a lack of understanding of the concept of sovereign risk .
the prime minister said at davos earlier this year what investors really need is greater confidence that governments wo n't change the rules after the investment has been made .
it seems mr warburton and his panel members disagree with the prime minister .
wwf-australia the report 's recommendations could see an extra 189 to 299 million tonnes of carbon pollution released between 2015 and 2030 .
that 's not what australians want .
they want pollution to go down not up .
lenore taylor 's news story .

investment in wind farms and other large scale renewables would dry up and subsidies for household solar power and electricity could cease under recommendations to the federal government from its review into the renewable energy target .

the recommendations from the review , chaired by businessman and self-professed climate sceptic dick warburton , are set to be opposed by labor , the greens and the palmer united party , setting the stage for another fight over climate policy in the upper house .

the issue has divided the cabinet , with tony abbott favouring the idea of closing the ret to any new investment , and climate change minister greg hunt and industry minister ian macfarlane fighting for it to be pared back rather than closed .
the review , which the prime minister took responsibility for when the coalition assumed government , includes abbott 's preferred option as one of two recommendations .
giles parkinson , writing in renew economy .

if the government accepts either of the ( ret review ) recommendations , australia would become the first country to either ditch a renewable energy target , or wind it back in much the same way as it was the first to scrap a carbon price .
meanwhile , down the front of the building .
aycc ( @ aycc ) @ murpharoo we 're down on parliament lawns calling on abbott to dump the review report in the bin - not renewables
the environment minister greg hunt is on sky news now .
sky political editor david speers asks him how the government will respond to the recommendations of the review .
we will look at it and respond over the coming weeks .
we have a long term commitment to renewable energy , but it 's about finding a balance .
speers persists .
given the coalition promised not to adjust the ret in its first term , will the government keep that promise ?
hunt says the coalition promised voters a 20 % target , and a review .
i 'm very mindful of our election commitments .
it 's a very strange experience , reading that report .
the essential conclusions are the ret scheme is working .
it 's not driving up electricity prices .
it 's doing its job .
the argument for winding it back is to reduce damaging emissions at lower cost .
as i 've noted , that sounds like an argument for a market mechanism to reduce carbon pollution .
it sounds like an argument for the scheme the government has just abolished .
if australia actually had a proper carbon price , you would n't actually need policies like a ret .
real alice through the looking glass stuff .
greens leader , christine milne .
christine milne ( @ senatormilne ) bin the ret review .
it is a disaster which will drive uncertainty , higher electricity bills and jobs offshore .
# climatedenierdrivel
john grimes , the head of the australian solar council , is on our office talking to my colleague lenore taylor .
he says if implemented , this report would decimate the solar industry .
again , direct from the report .

the small-scale renewable energy scheme ( sres ) the panel considers that there is a strong case for winding back the sres , through either closing the scheme immediately or accelerating the phase-out of the scheme .
the phase out option would see the scheme closed by 2020 .

in the interim there would be : additional measures to reduce the cost of the scheme , including earlier reductions in the levels of support ( certificate deeming periods ) provided for the installation of solar pv and solar water heater systems .

the panel also recommends reducing the size eligibility threshold for rooftop solar pv systems from no more than 100 kilowatts to no more than 10 kilowatts , to ensure the scheme is targeted towards households .
the report then goes through the likely implications of that policy change .
modelling indicates that repeal of the sres would have an immediate effect of reducing the install rates of rooftop pv by at least 30 % and the number of solar water heaters by around 16 % .
however , by the early 2020s , the rate of small-scale solar pv systems installed each year would recover to a rate similar to that if the sres was left in place .
here are the specific recommendations .
this material is taken from the ret review report .
large-scale renewable energy target ( lret ) there are two options proposed by the panel .
one : allow the lret to continue to operate until 2030 for existing and committed renewable generators , but closing it to new investment , otherwise known as grandfathering ' .

two : alternatively , the panel suggests that the lret could be modified to increase in proportion with growth in electricity demand , by setting targets one year in advance that correspond to a 50 % share of new growth .
if the current forecasts of electricity demand prove accurate , this approach would result in renewables making up a 20 % share of forecast electricity demand in 2020 .

targets would not be mandated for future years , exposing renewable energy investors to the same market risk ( that future levels of electricity demand are unknown ) that other investors in the sector currently face .
importantly , this approach would protect the broader community from the cost of subsidising unnecessary additional generation capacity if electricity demand continues to fall .

a bit more : with the renewables industry now established in australia , the main rationale for the ret hinges on its capacity to contribute towards the australian government 's co2 emissions reduction target in a cost effective manner .
however , the ret is a high cost approach to reducing co2 emissions because it does not directly target co2 emissions and it only focuses on electricity generation .
it promotes activity in renewable energy ahead of alternative , lower cost options for reducing co2 emissions that exist elsewhere in the economy .

although many representatives of the renewables sector favour at least maintaining the current ret , the panel is of the view that the interests of the broader community should take precedence and that , as the ret in its current form is imposing significant costs on the economy , it should be substantially reformed , with greater emphasis placed on lower cost alternatives for meeting the australian government 's co2 emissions reduction target .
from the ret review .

with the renewables industry now established in australia , the main rationale for the ret hinges on its capacity to contribute towards the government 's emissions reduction target in a cost effective manner .
however , the ret is a high cost approach to reducing emissions because it does not directly target emissions and it only focuses on electricity generation .
it promotes activity in renewable energy ahead of alternative , lower cost options for reducing emissions that exist elsewhere in the economy .
in the presence of lower cost alternatives , the costs imposed by the ret are not justifiable .
( sounds like an argument for carbon pricing . )
oooh .
snap .
tim stephens ( @ timstephens10 ) ret review `` the govt .
should emphasise lower cost approaches to reducing emissions . ''
what like the carbon price they abolished ?
# savetheret

documents.title: gut the ret , abbott told
text: the theme of the day is it 's all happening ' .
as i flagged earlier today , we 've been expecting the release of the review of the renewable energy target .
it 's just been posted .
i 'll cut right to the chase .
the report says gut the ret .

documents.title: australia and indonesia ink the new security `` understanding ''
text: the indonesian and australian foreign ministers are holding a press event to unveil a new understanding which pledges that the two countries wo n't use intelligence to damage one another 's interests .

today patches up the rift prompted by the snowden revelations , published by guardian australia last year , about the attempted tapping of the president 's mobile phone ; and tensions over the management of boat arrivals .
it sounds like peace love and harmony between marty natalegawa and julie bishop .
94a , an even bigger illustration .
mike bowers ( @ mpbowers ) 94a-ed a busy # qt for madam speaker @ twitterid @ twitterid # politicslive
further questions have been placed on the notice paper .
shorten is taking his colleagues on an mpi journey : why is tony abbott soooooo mean ?
in revenge for the prime minister quoting ben chifley earlier , shorten lobs menzies and his forgotten people .
your unfair budget has many forgotten people .
an inquiry from a reader via twitter .
kate m ( @ km2340 ) @ murpharoo would love some egs on live blog of what the opposition are thrown out for .
have never actually heard remains .
great job btw .
94a : an illustration .
bye bye chris .
shadow treasurer chris bowen gets 94a-ed during question time in the house of representatives , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers ( hi kate . )
labor folks are generally shown the door by madam speaker for abuses of the standing orders .
interjections across the chamber .
abuses of points of order .
this is not scientific , but i suspect the member for charlton , pat conroy , has been thrown out more often than any other labor member in this 44th parliament .
it 's fair to say conroy is deliberately provocative .
how the standing orders are deployed is of course a matter of interpretation .
madam speaker has a fairly sensitive trigger finger in that regard .
she 's inclined to show people the door with only limited provocation .
i know that 's a general summation , but hope that helps .
i think madam speaker has chucked out just about everyone in the opposition today .
a few reserved souls remain .
the member for canberra , gai brodtmann , is concerned about the fate of a canberra single mum who has a child with a rare auto-immune condition .
hockey is n't amused .
i remember the leader of the opposition sidling to me over there , saying please help me to take 60,000 women off the single mothers pension to put them on to the lesser payment of newstart . '
how about that ?
bill , do you remember that ?
labor lobs a double bunger question on cuts to family benefits and higher cost higher education .
treasurer joe hockey says both family benefits and university funding are subsidies .
that 's why the budget needs to be sustainable .
so people in the future can continue to be subsidised .
the government tracks back to carbon repeal savings .
happy days .
great news for all cafes , corner stores .
great news for pie warmers .
you 'll be able to afford to run your pie warmer and not risk an aggressive customer unhappy about a cold pie .
( that 's bruce billson , revving up shorten , who once had a tantrum about a cold pie . )
the education minister christopher pyne gets a dixer on higher education .

madam speaker then notes the presence of a number of venerables in the visitor 's gallery including shane stone , a former president of the liberal party , who famously advised the howard government about the perils of appearing mean and tricky .
labor is back on a promise abbott made 12 months ago .
labor 's deputy leader , tanya plibersek .

q : exactly one year ago today at a press conference in hobart the prime minister said , and i quote , we can fund the major initiatives that we have announced so far in this campaign without cutting health , without cutting education , without touching pensions .
so why is the prime minister breaking his promise by cutting $ 80bn from schools and hospitals and slashing $ 23bn from the age pension over the next decade ?
abbott : yet again , senior members of the opposition are simply wrong .
they are simply , simply wrong .
shadow treasurer , chris bowen , interjects with a point of order .
bowen : the prime minister 's being mean and tricky .
he 's misleading the house .
madam speaker shows him the door .
let 's have a paper war .

the leader of the opposition bill shorten taunts the prime minister with a letter from the australian war memorial during question time in the house of representatives , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers guardian australia bob katter had his own outburst .
displeased with the truss answer on qantas , he 's stalked out of the chamber .
the member for kennedy bob katter during question time in the house of representatives , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers guardian australia
now it 's war widows and pensions .
( there is a very odd shadow war in this question time .
one question from the opposition on the actual war and a number of questions on the matters related to war . )
q : why has the prime minister broken his word by cutting the indexation rate of war widows pensions ?
abbott : madam speaker , yet again the leader of the opposition is simply wrong .
he is simply wrong .
pensions go up every single year .
the leader of the opposition should stop running around the country scaring people , scaring people with lies .
labor is completely digging in on the memorial .
shadow finance minister tony burke .

q : given it was the previous labor government which announced the $ 10m he referred to in his previous answer , and given that both the war memorial and his own minister in the senate have confirmed that the $ 800,000 cut was a decision of this government , why is the prime minister breaking his promise to the australian war memorial ?
abbott is getting cranky now .
quite terse .
this is an opposition one of its members tried to play politics with national security earlier today and this is their response .
that is what it is .

this is a pathetic game from the leader of the opposition to cover up for the fact that one of his members tried to play politics with national security earlier on today and had to be pulled into line .
no-one supports the war memorial more than the members of this government .
in the house , labor is persisting on the war memorial .
abbott is persisting in arguing that funding has not been cut .
labor says the memorial says its funding has been cut .
abbott : to answer the member 's question as best i can , i want to stress that the $ 800,000 that he refers to has not been cut .
it has simply been reallocated , as i understand it , to other commemorative events .
labor 's jenny macklin interjects that the minister responsible for the war memorial has said the funding has been cut .
abbott ignores her : can i say this , in conclusion .
it really is odd that the labor party will choose to play politics over the australian war memorial .
shorten objects to the prime minister impugning labor .
abbott ploughs on .
i have made it absolutely crystal clear that funding for travelling exhibitions is $ 9.2m greater than would otherwise be the case .
madam speaker , it really is a little low of members opposite to try to play politics over the australian war memorial .
over in the other place , the government senate leader eric abetz is making heavy weather of iraq .
greens leader christine milne has asked abetz about the propsect of a troop deployment .
abetz deploys the irony font .
the alternative would be to send senator milne over there and say please stop .
bob katter asks the transport minister warren truss about qantas , given that $ 2bn loss .
truss counsels it 's not that bad .
the reality is that there is some encouragement for qantas shareholders in their report .
just a contribution from my colleague , daniel hurst .
over in the senate the attorney general , george brandis , has been laying out the case for bipartisanship on matters of national security .

brandis has welcomes bill shorten 's statement yesterday that the issue should be above politics , but it behoves all members of the senate to observe the injunction of mr shorten - a reference to labor senators who have accused the government of trying to distract from the budget .

brandis says labor has received five briefings about security matters by asio chief david irvine , officers of the attorney general 's department and brandis 's office and will continue to be kept informed .
the immigration minister scott morrison is invited to tell the house what he told neil mitchell mid morning .
morrison is duly telling the house what he told neil mitchell this morning .
the eyes of my officers will be closely watching .
today is obviously war on the war memorial day .
another labor question on funding cuts .
abbott says the government has n't cut support for the war memorial .
there 's a big exhibition .
why ca n't you people be happy about it , abbott wonders .
the government asks itself a question to run throught he security checklist once again .
then shorten is back on the war memorial .
q : in the year of the centenary of anzac , why has the prime minister cut the entire funding of the australian war memorial 's travelling exhibitions program ?
abbott says small travelling exhibitions wo n't be funded over the next few years , but a very large travelling exhibition is going to be funded .
the australian war memorial is the keeper of a sacred flame .
it is the place where we cherish the memory , the example , and the inspiration of all who have served our country , who have worn our country 's uniform , in time of peace and war .
we honour them , we salute them and we will suitably fund them over the centenary of anzac period .
the labor leader bill shorten opens today on iraq .
q : my question is to the prime minister .
can the prime minister provide an update on the situation in iraq and the role that australia will play ?
given the government says it wants bipartisan support , but has n't given labor a briefing about the latest developments , this question is not unexpected .
after a brief preamble about the murderous hoardes of islamic state , abbott says : i have to say that australia has not been officially asked for military assistance .
if we were asked for military assistance , there would be the standard approvals process that would involve cabinet decision making and consultation with the opposition .

i should say that should we be asked , we would want to look at any request in the light of achievable objectives , a clear role for australian forces , full risk assessment and an overall humanitarian objective .
but i do wish to say , madam speaker , that no-one in this parliament , i am sure , no human being anywhere , would wish to stand by and watch the preventible slaughter of innocent people .
then , the prime minister lobs chifley in the direction of the labor leader .

i 'm sure the leader of the opposition would not in this context mind me echoing the words of ben chifley and his light on the hill , to work for the betterment of man kind , not just here , but wherever we can lend a helping hand .
because that is the australian way , to keep our country safe and to do what we can to build a safer world .

documents.title: question time
text: amazingly , it is 2pm .
madam speaker is making a statement .
she wants to thank the security staff for ejecting a shouty man from the public gallery on tuesday .
nice work chaps .
hear hear , says the chamber .
pig equivalent .
reee-jected .

senator penny wong at the launch of australian pork limited 's five year strategic plan in parliament house canberra this afternoon , with apl 's chairman enzo allara ( left ) and ceo andrew spencer .
senator wong would not hold the cardboard pig fearing a savage vegetarian voter backlash .
thursday 28th august 2014 veganophobia .
the fear of vegans .
spies inform politics live that the shadow trade minister penny wong , displayed swineophobia at the pork function .
fearing a vicious vegetarian backlash , wong rebuffed entreaties to hold the cardboard pig .
i will not hold that pig , she is said to have said .
now , about this backdrop .
agriculture minister barnaby joyce launches australian pork limited 's five year strategic plan in parliament house canberra this afternoon , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers politics .
at a pork launch .
what could possibly go wrong ?
wilkie says the government is talking a lot about security , but if you actually look closer at the detail , the coalition is making a number of stumbles .
i think the government is actually making a number of missteps when it comes to national security .
that might surprise some people because this government thinks it 's strong on national security and it 's certainly beating its chest a lot at the moment .

but when you look at the fact that it 's pulling the federal police out of a capital city airport , not listening to the intelligence committee and continuing to refuse to bring into the parliament the question of whether or not we recommit combat forces to iraq when you add that all up you see a government that says a lot about national security , but is making a lot of missteps .
speaking of airports , independent andrew wilkie , on the abc , is objecting to the weakening of hobart airport .
wilkie says the government is pulling afp officers out of hobart airport .

wilkie : quite frankly history shows clearly that competent terrorists will be innovative and they will look for soft targets and we know that the main threat in australia now is this so-called home grown terrorist .

so it 's not about international airports and people flying in , it 's about the people in our midst who might want to cause mischief and the more you harden say sydney airport , melbourne airport and other mainland airports , the more you weaken hobart airport , the more vulnerable it becomes .

because of this government 's decision to pull the federal police out of hobart , and leave them in every other capital city airport it makes australia soft target and it puts us at risk and also makes hollow a certain amount of what the government is saying about this increased terrorist threat .
truss argues the qantas result was n't nearly as bad as it looked .
he says the airline is moving in the right direction .
the transport minister then gets a question about people detained at airports the people scott morrison pointed to earlier today .
he has no particulars to hand .
he suggests we ask the people who are talking about it .
q : on airport security , we 've heard the immigration minister today say there have been several people detained and questioned .
no charges it appears as yet .
would that have been different if there were these new terror laws , is that all that was holding them back from laying charges ?
i ca n't answer the question because i do n't have details of the particular people concerned and the specific arrangements or reasons for their detention .
so that 's a question you 'd better direct to minister scott morrison .
q : you mentioned volcanoes .
are these live volcanoes ?
truss : i do n't think so .
but there is evidence of them having emitted rocks and the like in the neighbourhood in the past .
there are questions about the costs associated with the search .
money was set aside in the may budget for this exercise .
truss : the total cost of the new tender is just above $ 52m australian , however , if we find the missing aircraft on the first day , it 's not going to cost that much obviously .
so the actual cost will depend on how long the search lasts .
the transport minister warren truss has reached an agreement with malaysia and china concerning the next stage in the search for the missing malaysian airlines flight mh370 .
the terms of the agreement are being outlined at a press conference now .
truss : all of the countries involved remain cautiously optimistic that we will find the missing aircraft .
starting next month , the australian transport safety bureau will lead a deep sea search using an australian contracted vessel discovery ' and equator ' and a malaysian vessel .
the malaysian vessel will be the first on the site and will be there in three weeks time .
the vessels will search the floor using tow ed vehicles , with multi-beam echo sounders , video cameras , all deployed to locate this aircraft .
the high resolution search of the priority area on the sea floor is expected to take about 12 months to complete .
together the vessels will search this area in a systematic way so that we can be sure that the area is thoroughly covered .
he mentions the search has located quite remarkable geographical features , including a couple of volcanoes .

documents.title: politics this lunchtime
text: some of my colleagues in canberra are objecting to the fact that i have censored clive palmer 's close encounter with the men 's room .
they seem not to realise that free speech is so yesterday .
let 's press on with the lunchtime summary .

thursday , thus far : the defence minister david johnston has confirmed australian planes are deployed in the region and waiting for a call from washington , but he 's indicated that nothing of a decisive nature is likely to happen in northern iraq before the second week in september .
labor says it has not yet been updated by the abbott government about the latest developments in washington .
shadow foreign affairs minister tanya plibersek has urged caution about any military interventions that range more widely than the obligation to protect .
it did n't work in 2003 .
it 's unlikely to work now , is her rationale .
the higher education reforms have been introduced to the house of representatives .
universities say pass the package with amendments .
tertiary education unions say do n't pass it at all .
pup leader clive palmer has played down suggestions of a rift between jacqui lambie and glenn lazarus .

documents.title: they will be uniformed
text: the immigration minister scott morrison has been on 3aw in melbourne as part of the keeping us safe at airports ' offensive .
morrison has told his host neil mitchell that ten threats present at australian airports every day .
he also continues to specify the airports that targeted customs resources will go to particularly in sydney and melbourne .
( labor raised an issue with this sort of oversharing earlier today it 's basically giving people a heads up .
is this really wise ?
but let 's not digress . )
mitchell is a bit perplexed by this ten threats a day metric .
q : when you say ten threats a day , you mean ten individuals ?
morrison : yes .
q : that you are worried about coming in or going out ?
morrison : yes .
( but then , some fine print . )
now that is not specifically in relation to counter terrorism .
there are many reasons why an alert might present at an airport , it could be transnational crime , it could be criminal activity , it could be any number of different things and that is my point .

our border team every day has to deal with a wide range of threats which can be physical , they can be criminal , they can be national security , any number of these types of things and this an added threat and the government has responded by putting additional resources in and ensuring that we can as far as is humanly possible ensure that our airports and our borders are as tight as they can be .
q : so will these counter terrorism units be covert or will they be obvious ?
morrison : no they will be there .
they will be obvious , they will be uniformed .
q : ok. what will they actually do ?
morrison says these customs counter-terrorism officials have a higher clearance to enable them to engage particularly with other agencies .
the immigration minister says there have been five interdictions at airports in recent times .
ahead of formalities later in bali concerning the new intelligence agreement with indonesia , the foreign minister julie bishop has held a brief media conference .
this is her formulation on australian involvement in iraq .
bishop : we have been very supportive of the us air strikes which seem to have had some impact on the humanitarian crisis , and has averted in some instances the siege in mount sinjar .
if there is any further request for australia to support efforts to disrupt and defeat isil , we will certainly consider them .
it would be based on an assessment of risk , what achievable humanitarian purpose might be available and , of course , what clear and proportionate role there would be for australia .
q : has there been a request made to date ?
we are waiting to hear from the united states on further plans .
i believe the united states is in discussion with a number of countries .

we 've indicated to the united states we stand ready to receive any further requests from them but it will be assessed , as i indicated , against risk and the clear and proportionate role australia could take .
we are focused on ensuring that isis can be defeated , its barbaric ways can be stopped .
likewise , we want to ensure those australians who are attracted to fighting with isis in syria and iraq can be prevented from doing so .
we would rather prevent terrorism than have to prosecute terrorists after they had taken part in terrorist activities .
politics live readers who also follow the political conversation via social media will be aware more than likely that clive palmer has shared something of his digestive habits with reporters .
a little window into scheduling in a busy public life .
i 'm going to leave that conversation there .
censored
time waits for no time poor attorney-general .

quick dash across the courtyard in the direction of the ministerial wing .

documents.title: look forward to seeing you at the range : has goodenough jumped the gun ?
text: my colleague helen davidson has been hot on the trail of a story involving pistol shooting , and our elected representatives .
yes , i am serious .
take it away helen .
competitive shooting might be added to the list of sports on offer at the canberra parliament sports festival this year , after extensive lobbying by two coalition mps .

liberal member for the western australian seat of moore , ian goodenough , emailed his parliamentary colleagues on thursday to announce that after much lobbying by him and victorian nationals senator bridget mckenzie , he 'd been advised pistol shooting will be a part of the september sports festival open to all parliamentary employees and their families .
i understand that both rimfire and centrefire events will most probably be offered , wrote goodenough , inviting his colleagues to register their interest .
look forward to seeing you at the range !
however goodenough may have jumped the gun , as ceo of the australian parliamentary sports club , andy turnbull , told guardian australia he has not made a decision yet .
competitive shooting has n't been added yet , he said .
the pistol plot thickens
# teampup
palmer 's comments about lambie and lazarus relate to a pda the two engaged in down at the national press club this morning .
hugs .
general stooged lavishness .
god spare us .
pup leader clive palmer with the premier of south australian jay weatherill at a press conference in parliament house canberra this morning , thursday 28th august 2014 bowers
palmer says he has not considered whether or not australia should join a us-led coalition in iraq .
there is only so much one can turn one 's mind to .
q : has jacqui lambie done a side deal with the government on the roads to recovery legislation ?
what agreement has been struck with the government on that bill ?
palmer : we as a party , me as leader , has not struck an agreement , that 's true , but jacqui lambie had her own individual discussions .
i 'm not privy .
q : are you upset she is having her own discussions with the ministers about issues like this and they are not going through you ?
no , because we live in a democracy .
we 've got a thing called freedom .
one of those things is freedom of speech and ability to express your views .
q : what happens if she votes with the government on this , you are not going to be upset ?
she has n't done that .
q : she could .
so could i. i could vote with the government occasionally , too .
q : peter dutton and to some extent christopher pyne seem to be implying you are doing one thing in private and another in public .
is that the case ?
this was a question to palmer .
government folks do suggest privately that the pup crowd are prone to saying one thing in a private meeting and another thing when there is a tv camera present .

palmer : we have got a responsibility to the people of australia to listen to the ministers they 've elected and see what they 've got to say , come to terms with it , discuss it with our fellow senators because i do n't make all the decisions , get their comments and make a decision .
we 've also got a responsibility once we have made that decision to communicate it to the people of australia and to them .
i wrote a letter to mr pyne telling him our senators had resolved unanimously not to support the education reforms .
i felt duty-bound to make a statement on the co-payment .
we have been very clear .
now , to splitsville in pupsville .
q : what are relationships like between jacqui lambie and glenn lazarus ?
i normally do n't answer those questions but i will because you are such a nice guy .
you should have come to our press conference .
he was holding her hands , she gave him a big kiss on the cheek .
i have never seen julia bishop [ sic ] kiss tony abbott .
i have never seen tanya plabersek [ sic ] kiss bill shorten .
i am happy if anybody wants to kiss me .
clive maths .
a tutorial .
palmer was asked about whether he 'd support a compromise model on the co-payment put forward by the ama .
the ama says they will take the co-payment and put it in their pockets .
if we think of the doctors getting six minutes to charge out , they get an extra $ 7 every six minutes , that means $ 70 an hour more .
over a 40 hour week , earning an extra $ 2,800 a year .
do i think paying our doctors an extra $ 2,800 above what they are earning now is a solution for our poor people ?
i do n't think it is .
( $ 2,800 a week , this calculation , i think . )
pup boss clive palmer is facing journalists in the courtyard with south australian premier jay weatherill .
palmer is opening on the co-payment .
the pup announced this week the $ 7 gp co-payment was dead in the water .
weatherill is here for a senate select committee hearing later on this morning about health .
palmer : the co-payment is a drastic attack on the sick and elderly of our society and does n't offer much hope for any of us as australians .
weatherill says it 's terrible that the coalition cut state health budgets on budget night with no warning .
what happened to shared responsibility ?
it 's absolutely essential that both levels of government have skin in the game for the management of our public hospital system .
you can see what happens when they do n't think that way .

you get crazy ideas like the medicare co-payment which will mean that people will avoid going to the doctor , so bronchitis will turn into pneumonia and they 'll be presenting at our emergency departments .
or you 'll have people avoiding the medicare co-payment by presenting into the emergency departments clogging them up .
weatherill says he 'll be taking his do n't americanise our health system ' message to the senate committee and to crossbenchers .
there have been two education related press conferences over the past little bit .
i 've already reported the position of universities australia : pass the package , but with amendments .
the university education union has a different message .
jeannie rea , nteu national president : pyne 's package will be bad for students and many of our universities and communities .
it should be rejected outright .
the nteu says the package will create a two tiered education system , and that is undesirable .
looking ahead .
the government is expect to release later today the review of the renewable energy target which has been undertaken by businessman dick warburton .
the government is also expected to tie up a new bilateral agreement with indonesia setting out the terms of intelligence gathering .
the break neck pace of the morning has not allowed me to reference until now reports of trouble in the pup mill .
the news corp tabloids are reporting jacqui lambie is cranky with glenn lazarus , and is flirting with the notion of departing the kennel .
clive palmer has a media event coming up this morning .
woops .
some breaking news from my colleague paul farrell .
the australian federal police mistakenly published highly sensitive information including metadata connected to criminal investigations , in a serious breach of operational security .

guardian australia can reveal that the afp provided documents to the senate , which were then made publicly available online on parliamentary sites and other sources for several years , and which accidentally disclosed information about the subjects and focus of criminal investigations and telecommunications interception activities .

the revelations are an embarrassment for the law enforcement agency and the federal government , which are pushing for a mandatory data retention scheme to force telecommunications companies to retain personal data from phone and web users .
my colleague daniel hurst is already burrowing into the higher education bill in search of new facts .
he 's discovered one .
the legislation reveals the government will fund places at private colleges at 70 % of the rate it funds universities .
daniel tells me this specific funding ratio has n't been revealed until today .
greens deputy leader adam bandt is n't chuckling about iraq .
it seems that the drums of war are beating louder but the prime minister still has n't made that case that bombing another country will make the australia any safer .

we need to learn the lessons of the last decade and understand that foreign involvement in iraq has actually contributed to making things worse and there are real questions about what it will mean for australia 's safety and potential blowback if australian gets involved in bombing another country .
these questions should be brought out in the open and debate in parliament before we commit this country to another war that may last for another decade .
the prime minister must today come to the parliament and explain whether or not australian troops and forces are about to be involved in another war .
peak pyne ?
the minister for education christopher pyne during a division in the house of representatives in parliament house this morning , thursday 28th august 2014 .
bowers
the lobby group representing the university sector is n't sure whether the worst has passed or not .
universities australia has issued a statement calling in the senate to pass the coalition 's higher education package but only if it is amended .
ua chief executive , belinda robinson : under the current student loans scheme , fees are deferred until students graduate and earn over $ 53,000 per annum and interest is calculated at cpi .
universities australia urges the senate to maintain the cpi interest rate so no one with the ability to attend university is saddled with a large debt .
similarly we call on the senate to moderate the size of the proposed 20 per cent cut in the government contribution to tuition fees so as to reduce upward price pressure on fees .

it is also critical , as with any substantial industry change brought about by changes to policy settings , that a package of support be provided to universities , particularly those that serve disadvantaged and regional communities .
qantas boss alan joyce is meanwhile telling everyone everything is ok .
it will all be ok. we have now come through the worst .
( boy , you 'd hope so . )
team labor have bobbed up at tilley 's cafe in lyneham .
labor leader bill shorten is back on the budget .

labor will fight and fight and fight and fight and fight shorten : pensioners have the right to be able to have a little bit extra so they can give $ 5 to their grand kids when the kids visit they are people who deserve after a lifetime of paying taxes and contributing to the community not to be attacked by this government with their unfair budget .
for those interested in having a look at the legislation that has just been introduced , you can find it here .

the minister for education christopher pyne introduces the higher education and research amendment bill into the house of representatives in parliament house this morning , thursday 28th august 2014 .
bowers the passage of the reform bill will enable australia to achieve the best higher education system in the world and have some of the best universities in the world .
we live in a time of constant change .
the international economy is evolving , the employment market is shifting and tomorrow 's jobs demand different skills to the jobs of today .

currently our universities are at risk of being left behind and overtaken by the growing university systems in our region and across the globe as these systems increase their capacity and new forms of online and blended delivery take hold .
we must aspire to not only keep up with our competitors , but keep ahead of them .

the government 's changes will give australian universities the freedom and autonomy to work to their strengths , be internationally competitive and manage economic and social changes to the best of their abilities .
pyne says in his second reading speech that quality is everything .
it 's just rhetotic , sure but that statement goes to the heart of the values embedded in this higher ed package .
this package is about prioritising quality over universal access .
that 's a simplification , sure , but not much of a simplification .
the sandstone universities want the freedom to teach fewer students and charge the students they teach more .
they want the freedom to be elite institutions , not mass market education factories .
in australia , various reforms dating from the whitlam period have prioritised opening up university education to everyone .
this package really does change the prevailing public policy disposition of the past thirty years or so .
it 's only fair that they pay a reasonable share of what it costs the taxpayer .
back to pyne , who is speaking about how australian university students go on to earn much more over the course of their careers than kids who do n't go on to higher education .
only reasonable that they cover some of the subsidy they get , is his rationale .
while pyne is talking i should note that qantas is prompting the screen jockeys to reach for the smelling salts .
australia 's national carrier has just posted a $ 2.8bn annual loss .
no-one expected a result that bad .
the house of representatives has gathered now to consider the higher education bills .
pyne is on his feet .
he says the objective of this package the most substantial set of higher ed reforms since the dawkins package in the late 1980s is to have some of the best universities in the world .
pyne : we must aspire not only to keep up with our competitors , but to keep ahead of them .
pyne contends deregulation is the only way to respond to what students want , and what the university sector needs .
it 's the only bulwark against mediocrity .
here 's another lovely shot from mr bowers .

the greens adam bandt , minister for education christopher pyne and the shadow education minister kate ellis await their turn to speak on camera at the ritual known as reps doors of parliament house in canberra thursday 28th august 2014 bowers lovely , in that it tells a story behind the story .
people outside canberra and outside the aquarium of parliament house will only see news grabs of various spokespeople trading blows on various policies .
you never see this bit , when foes hang about with each other in convivial fashion .
here was christopher pyne , labor 's kate ellis , and greens deputy leader adam bandt , having a laff , before turning the rhetorical guns on one another about the higher ed package .
the coalition 's higher education reforms cleared the party room this week .
i gather there was some discussion around the policy but in any case , the package was approved , and it 's hitting the house of representatives .
pyne is up to his fourth interview of the morning .
students are getting a fabulous deal .
the key points he 's trying to make are : students are being asked to pay 50 % of the cost of their university education .
this is n't unreasonable .
if the university takes the opportunity of deregulation to charge fees that are unreasonably high , then students will go somewhere else .
on the matter of the package being friendless in the senate , pyne has said this .
i still believe the momentum is with these reforms .
i have a lot of energy .
i intend to press ahead with these reforms .
good morning mike bowers .
the minister for education christoipher pyne on his way to an interview in the press gallery of parliament house in canberra this morning , thursday 28th august 2014 .
bowers i love bowers for many reasons .
but my particular love stems from his talent for the visual story .
here 's the education minister christopher pyne , on his way to various radio interviews this morning .
as i 've tried to flag , the higher education reforms are in the parliament today .
pyne is therefore required to hit peak spruik .
you 'll see in this he 's about to pass the furphy 's farm water cart .
this artwork used to live in old parliament house .
it has recently turned up in the parliamentary press gallery .
for those who do n't know their history , the furphy 's water carts were used in world war one .
they became places around which diggers would gather and tell tall tales .
the furphy carts therefore epitomise unreliable information .
perfect to locate this work near us , in other words .
i 'll post pyne 's spruiking in a minute and you can be the judge of whether the unreliable information extends beyond the art of political journalists .
sorry i will get to education in a minute , i really will .
captain cronulla has cut across my effort to point you all towards the introduction today of the government 's higher education reforms .
the immigration minister scott morrison has hit the airwaves to tell australians how safe they are at airports .
he 's on the abc 's am program .
host michael brissenden asks morrison when the government intends to bring labor more substantively into the loop on these security issues , given the government says it wants bipartisan support .
q : clearly you want bipartisan support for these new laws .
but there have been a lot of press conferences and a lot of media releases .
when will we see the legislation and how can you expect the opposition to fully support you without seeing it ?
morrison : we have to wait for that legislation to be in the domain where others can view it .
of course that 's the process .
i would think that there would be an agreement about the serious nature of the threat .
the opposition have had briefings on these types of issues .
captain cronulla also notes his disappointment with labor senator sue lines .
lines has argued over the past 24 hours that the government is flooring the national security accelerator in order to distract from the fact it ca n't get the budget through the parliament .
morrison : i 'm very disappointed with senator lines ' comments .
if she does n't believe that the is involvement in iraq and syria presents a genuine and real threat to australia then she is a muppet .
just before i shift modes to education , i should note that plibersek was also asked about the government 's national security reforms .
fran kelly on radio national breakfast asked whether plibersek knew anymore about whether the legislative package dealing with foreign fighters would see a reverse onus of proof .

the government up until yesterday had been signalling that the looming change to the law would see australians travelling to iraq or syria having to prove they had been in the region for an innocent purpose , rather than being thought innocent until proven guilty .
the foreign minister , julie bishop , repositioned yesterday .
she said it would remain up to authorities to prove guilt or innocence .
kelly wanted to know what labor knew , given bishop said yesterday the opposition had been fully briefed on the security package .
well , no , plibersek said .
labor had been given a couple of briefings about the intent of the package .
it had seen absolutely no content .
plibersek also noted the government seemed to be developing policy on the fly in this space .

she said , by way of example , she was alarmed that yesterday , the government had made an announcement about beefing up customs capacity at australian airports to ensure people on security watch lists did n't flee the country .
in the announcement , the prime minister was clear and precise about which airports had the beefed up capacity and which airports did not have the beefed up capacity .
this was a bit of a problem was n't it ?
telling people which airports had less security screening capacity .
bit of a give away .
( good point , this . )
so given all the content in that opening post ( curse that waterfall of breaking news ) let 's be clear about where things stand iraq-wise .
the government has essentially confirmed australian military assets are deployed in the region waiting for the us call .
the defence minister has indicated things will most likely move from theory to action in the middle of september .
but labor says it has no information from the government about these events .
the opposition is also saying an intervention in iraq in 2003 made things worse .
labor is saying we need to tread very carefully here .
good morning everyone and welcome to thursday .
iraq is dominating the morning news cycle .
the key developments in the last 24 hours are the us has clearly lifted its tempo .
all the signs are washington is intent on building a new coalition of the willing , and that will include australia .
australia has left open the option of participating in airstrikes provided certain criteria is met .
on last night 's lateline program , the defence minister david johnston indicated australian raaf super hornets were incredibly capable .
super hornets were an obvious first port of call were we to consider it necessary to participate with our friends and our ally .
he confirmed the planes were at a high state of readiness .
but then , something of a reality check on timing .
everyone , johnston said , was waiting for a stable government in baghdad .
and that 's not going to occur until 10th september when the new prime minister takes over .
then there was a need to settle rules of engagement .
we 'll need to do a whole host of things before we start talking about any form of deployment .
johnston noted these things are not just done at the turn of a key , although they may seem as much .
so there 's a long way to go before we start talking about deploying these sorts of systems into the field .
so closer to action , sure , but not yet close .
by the by , if you happen to be looking for one , here 's good news wrap which also takes in the current disposition towards the conflict in london right now .
interestingly , labor 's foreign minister , tanya plibersek , is making it clear that the opposition is out of the loop .
she says labor has sought a briefing on the latest developments , but thus far , that has not been forthcoming .
plibersek is on radio national breakfast .
she 's asked whether labor would support a more forceful intervention .
plibersek is n't saying one way or another .
we 'd have to get more information about what 's being requested of us .
if there is a potential genocide , the international community has a responsibility to protect .
it does look as though there are potential genocides in northern iraq and certainly , a genocidal campaign both in syria and iraq .
but the type of any action that australia might take i think that is something that we need to be very thoughtful and very calm about .
the war in 2003 was not just damaging for australia , for the united states , for all of the countries that were involved .
i think it 's been very damaging for iraq as well .
we need to be very cautious and not do more harm than good .
it really is all happening .
the politics live comments thread is wide open for your business .
you can talk to me on twitter @ twitterid or to the man with the lens @ twitterid

Gut the RET, Abbott told

Australia and Indonesia ink the new security "understanding"

Look forward to seeing you at the range: has Goodenough jumped the gun?

bulletin.text: MPs are in Canberra for the final parliamentary sitting day of the week. All the developments from Canberra, live.
